pullRequest.body:
Introduces a new module, `Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.FixedPoints`,
which contains some properties of `MulAction.fixedBy` that wouldn't quite belong to `Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Basic`.

---

This is my first contribution ever to Mathlib, and the first contribution in a series of contributions to eventually merge [my formalization of Rubin's theorem](https://github.com/adri326/rubin-lean4/) into Lean.

I have a few questions around the design decisions that I took:

- ~~should `movedBy` be defined in `Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.Basic` instead?~~
- `Mathlib.GroupTheory.GroupAction.FixingSubgroup` uses `M` for a group, would it be out-of-scope for this PR to also replace it with `G`?
- should I try to further minimize the usage of tactic groups?
- I'm trying to translate the properties that I will need later for the formalization of Rubin's theorem, so I wonder if `not_commute_of_disjoint_movedBy_preimage` might be too out-of-scope

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I fixed the above issues; the CI should pass, as I haven't changed any public-facing interfaces.

I fixed the issues pointed out by @riccardobrasca, as well as some I noticed in the meantime (some theorems were named `pow` when they referred to `zpow`).

I would like to say that trying to get this first pull request merged has been a pretty demotivating experience so far:
there is no proper linter or formatter that I could run locally,
building documentation locally is extremely slow and the instructions for doing so are poorly documented, etc.

The backlog of pull requests means that each round of small issue that could be caught ahead of time with proper tooling instead adds at least a day before this pull request gets approved. I understand the need to have PRs be properly reviewed, but I long for tools to reduce these reviews down to the more impactful issues.

> I fixed the issues pointed out by @riccardobrasca, as well as some I noticed in the meantime (some theorems were named `pow` when they referred to `zpow`).
> 
> I would like to say that trying to get this first pull request merged has been a pretty demotivating experience so far: there is no proper linter or formatter that I could run locally, building documentation locally is extremely slow and the instructions for doing so are poorly documented, etc.
> 
> The backlog of pull requests means that each round of small issue that could be caught ahead of time with proper tooling instead adds at least a day before this pull request gets approved. I understand the need to have PRs be properly reviewed, but I long for tools to reduce these reviews down to the more impactful issues.

I am sorry this has been a painful experience.

One thing to keep in mind is that last week there was a pretty important Lean conference, so a lot of people didn't have time to review PRs: we know that it is a slow process, but maybe you were just unlucky.

Can you please copy/paste this message on Zulip? It is very possible that some of tools you want exist, but are maybe not very well documented (for example you can run all the linters locally, it is just slow).

> (for example you can run all the linters locally, it is just slow).

If you have enough local compute `make lint` is all that it takes to run the linter locally.

Automatic code formatting is definitely on the roadmap!

I replaced `movedBy α g` with `(fixedBy α g)ᶜ`, and added some helper lemmas around `s ∈ fixedBy (Set α) g`. I tried having `abbrev` but it made `rw` only work sporadically, and I couldn't get `notation` to work like I wanted to.

This was quite the refactor so I wouldn't be surprised if I accidentally re-introduced small issues in there.
@tb65536 haven't heard back in a little while, are there other design patterns that are problematic with this PR?

LGTM! Thanks for adding all this API

maintainer merge

Thanks!

```suggestion
  rw [mem_fixedBy, zpow_smul_eq_iff_minimalPeriod_dvd,
    minimalPeriod_eq_one_of_fixedBy a_in_fixedBy]
```

```suggestion
  rw [← compl_compl (fixedBy α m), movedBy_eq_compl_fixedBy]
```
I noticed this style issue in the meantime, yeah

```suggestion
  repeat rw [← not_mem_fixedBy_iff_mem_movedBy]
```

```suggestion
  rw [← Set.compl_inter, Set.compl_subset_compl]
```

```suggestion
  rw [← smul_pow_preimage_eq_of_movedBy_subset t_superset j]
```

```suggestion
    rwa [← ne_eq, ← mem_movedBy, moved_empty] at ma_ne_a
```

This closing bracket should move to the previous line.
Alternatively, consider starting the tactic proof (`by`-block) on line 263, and splitting into two parts with `constructor`.
I did the latter, since most of the proof was in a `by`-block anyway
Should `α` be explicit here?
It should, yes, although someone should probably do an automated pass on the entirety of mathlib because I've had to manually force-provide arguments several times
Can you please check that the name generated by `to_additive` is correct?
I'll do that, although I think the name should be the same, it will just be in the `AddAction` context.
I just wanted to check that the `one` doesn't become `zero`.
Oh, good point!
You were right, it substituted it with a `zero`
Same here, should `α` be explicit?
Same.

You can write
```lean
variable (M) in
```
just before a lemma to avoid to make `M` explicit and then implicit again.

```suggestion
    fixedBy α g ⊆ fixedBy α (g ^ j) := by
```
And similar elsewhere (not very important of course, but I think this style is more common in mathlib).
The tactic `by_cases` does exactly this and it is nicer.
I do miss the convenience of NNG's `cases`, since I never remember the name of the generated subgoals, and you need to name them explicitely to be able to access the generated hypothesis

I mean you can do this
```lean
/-- If `movedBy α g ⊆ s`, then `g` cannot move a point of `s` outside of `s`. -/
@[to_additive "If `movedBy α g ⊆ s`, then `g` cannot move a point of `s` outside of `s`."]
theorem smul_zpow_mem_of_movedBy_subset {a : α} {s : Set α} {g : G} (s_subset : movedBy α g ⊆ s)
    (j : ℤ) : g ^ j • a ∈ s ↔ a ∈ s := by
  by_cases h : a ∈ movedBy α (g ^ j)
  · constructor
    all_goals (intro; apply s_subset)
    all_goals apply movedBy_zpow_subset_movedBy g j
    · exact h
    · rw [smul_mem_movedBy_iff_mem_movedBy]
      exact h
  · rw [not_mem_movedBy_iff_mem_fixedBy, mem_fixedBy] at h
    rw [h]
```

```suggestion
/-- If `movedBy α g ⊆ t`, then `g` cannot send a subset of `t` outside of `t`. -/
```

I don't remember if we have to specify the docstring to `to_additive`, can you please check this?

Same below. If not then above you repeated the docstring.
We do, yeah

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (a_in_fixedBy : a ∈ AddAction.fixedBy α g) : ```
Please swap LHS with RHS and mark it as a `simp` lemma.
Done, I avoided introducing new simp lemmas but this one is straightforward enough
Naming convention says that this should be called `smul_movedBy`.
Someone can correct me if I'm wrong, but I think `Type*` is preferred over explicit universes?
I can't find where this is said, but from a quick ripgrep there seems to be a lot more instances of `Type*` than `universe`
With these variables, if you ever use `M` and `G` in the same theorem, then it won't be universe polymorphic.

```suggestion
  rw [mem_fixedBy, mem_fixedBy, inv_smul_eq_iff, eq_comm]
```

```suggestion
  rwa [Function.minimalPeriod_eq_one_iff_isFixedPt]
```

```suggestion
  rwa [Function.minimalPeriod_eq_one_iff_isFixedPt]
```

```suggestion
  rw [mem_fixedBy, zpow_smul_eq_iff_minimalPeriod_dvd,
    minimalPeriod_eq_one_of_fixedBy a_in_fixedBy, Nat.cast_one]
```

```suggestion
  simp
```
or
```suggestions
  simp_rw [mem_fixedBy, one_smul, Set.mem_univ]
```
This one I'm unsure if I agree; I can just have `Set.eq_univ_iff_forall.mpr (fun a => one_smul M a)`, though

Here's an alternate proof, not because I'm suggesting you adopt it, but because it indicates to me that the "substance" of this lemma is `g • s = s` (`g` takes `s` to `s`). So I wonder whether some of your later results might be better phrased in this pointwise manner. For instance, `smul_zpow_mem_fixedBy_of_commute` could be phrased as `Commute g h → h • fixedBy α g = fixedBy α g`.

```
have h1 : g • s = s
  · ext a
    by_cases h : g • a = a
    · rw [Set.mem_smul_set_iff_inv_smul_mem, ← h, inv_smul_smul, h]
    rw [Set.mem_smul_set_iff_inv_smul_mem]
    exact iff_of_true (s_subset (smul_inv_mem_movedBy_iff_mem_movedBy.mpr h)) (s_subset h)
  have h2 : g ^ j • s = s
  · exact fixedBy_subset_fixedBy_zpow (Set α) g j h1
  rw [← Set.ext_iff.mp h2 (g ^ j • a), Set.smul_mem_smul_set_iff]
```

You are right, if I go with the pointwise smul route, then I can re-use a lot of the theorems from above (since `g • s = s` is definitionally equal to `s ∈ fixedBy (Set α) g`). I was wary of using pointwise smul, because they are used rarely enough that I didn't know about it for a while at first.
Is just writing `(fixedBy α m)ᶜ` everywhere an option, or are some things too painful?

There are a few works out there that chain operations with this structure, which they usually call the "support" of the action; this is the case in Rubin's theorem. I don't mind changing this to an `abbrev` or `notation`, though, and that would probably allow me to drop a few theorems. I guess `(fixedBy a m)^c` isn't too wordy, but I'll encounter the same issue later with the `fixingSubgroup` of the complement of a set, which has a few nice properties and is used heavily in the proof of Rubin's theorem
Maybe `fixedBy_inv` is a nicer name?

Minor, but no need for `x` here
```suggestion
  ext
```

Maybe upgrade this to an `iff`?
```suggestion
@[to_additive minimalPeriod_eq_one_iff_fixedBy]
theorem minimalPeriod_eq_one_iff_fixedBy {a : α} {g : G} :
    Function.minimalPeriod (fun x => g • x) a = 1 ↔ a ∈ fixedBy α g :=
  Function.minimalPeriod_eq_one_iff_isFixedPt
```

Minor golf:
```suggestion
  Set.eq_univ_iff_forall.mpr (one_smul M)
```

I would suggest just cleaning up the statement of this theorem and deleting one or the other.
```suggestion
theorem fixedBy_conj (g h : G) : fixedBy α (h * g * h⁻¹) = h • fixedBy α g := by
  ext a
  rw [Set.mem_smul_set_iff_inv_smul_mem, mem_fixedBy, mem_fixedBy]
```
I chose to stick with `smul_fixedBy`, since it's the one I'm using the most in my other branches

```suggestion
  simp_rw [mem_fixedBy, ← eq_inv_smul_iff, Set.ext_iff, Set.mem_inv_smul_set_iff]
```
Usually we would put the more complicated expression on the left side of the `iff`, so that it `rw`'s naturally.

```suggestion
    (s_in_fixedBy : s ∈ fixedBy (Set α) g) : g • t ⊆ s :=
  (Set.set_smul_subset_set_smul_iff.mpr t_ss_s).trans s_in_fixedBy.subset
```

```suggestion
    h ^ j • fixedBy α g = fixedBy α g :=
```

If you add a lemma
```
@[to_additive]
lemma Set.smul_compl (g : G) (s : Set α) : g • sᶜ = (g • s)ᶜ := by
  rw [Set.compl_eq_univ_diff, Set.smul_set_sdiff, Set.smul_set_univ, Set.compl_eq_univ_diff]
```
then this can become
```suggestion
  rw [mem_fixedBy, Set.smul_compl, fixedBy_mem_fixedBy_of_commute comm]
```
I ended up writing this lemma in the meantime, I probably have it in other PRs already. Might as well get that lemma merged now :)

```suggestion
theorem smul_zpow_fixedBy_eq_of_commute {g h : G} (comm : Commute g h) (j : ℤ) :
```

```suggestion
theorem smul_zpow_movedBy_eq_of_commute {g h : G} (comm : Commute g h) (j : ℤ) :
```

```suggestion
  rw [← (smul_left_injective' (M := M) (α := α)).eq_iff, Set.eq_univ_iff_forall]
  simp_rw [Function.funext_iff, one_smul, mem_fixedBy]
```

```suggestion
  contrapose! ne_one with comm
  rwa [movedBy_mem_fixedBy_of_commute comm, disjoint_self, Set.bot_eq_empty, Set.compl_empty_iff,
    fixedBy_eq_univ_iff_eq_one] at disjoint
```
What is `movingSubgroup`?
Ah, I see. It's the fixing subgroup of the complement. Are you still planning on adding this, or should this TODO be removed?
No, I'm not going to add it for the same reason that `movedBy` was scrapped

```suggestion
  simp_rw [mem_fixingSubgroup_iff, Set.subset_def, mem_fixedBy]
```

```suggestion
  rw [mem_fixingSubgroup_iff_subset_fixedBy, Set.compl_subset_comm]
```

```suggestion
theorem orbit_fixingSubgroup_compl_subset {s : Set α} {a : α} (a_in_s : a ∈ s) :
  MulAction.orbit (fixingSubgroup M sᶜ) a ⊆ s := by
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(GroupTheory/GroupAction): new `FixedPoints` module with a few basic properties of `fixedBy`

source.title: chore: Replace `Function.minimalPeriod (m • ·) a` with `MulAction.period m a`
